thread.title: U-M mega donor Stephen Ross to tackle racism, bullying in sports
thread.title_full: U-M mega donor Stephen Ross to tackle racism, bullying in sports

author: freep.com
title: U-M mega donor Stephen Ross to tackle racism, bullying in sports
text:
MORE Stephen Ross, billionaire owner of the Miami Dolphins and huge donor to the University of Michigan, is launching a nationwide media campaign today to support his Ross Initiative for Sports and Equality (RISE), a multipronged effort to help kids combat racism and stop bullying.
And Ross, a native Detroiter and graduate of both U-M's business school and Wayne State University's law school, has chosen to kick off this crusade in southeast Michigan on this weekend of the UM-Michigan State football game and the 50th anniversary reunion of his WSU law class.
Oh, and he's picked Detroit PAL, which runs sports programs for 13,000 Detroit kids, as one of RISE's first youth partners.
Also pledging to spread the RISE message of respect and equality are likes of football quarterback Tom Brady, basketball stars LeBron James and Draymond Green and the nation's leading professional and college sports organizations from the NCAA and Major League Baseball to leagues for football, basketball, hockey, soccer, golf and volleyball players.
Tom Brady, pictured on Jan. 22, 2015 in Foxboro, Massachusetts. (Photo: Photo by Maddie Meyer/Getty Images)
In a series of public service announcements (PSAs) launching today on the website RISEtoWin.org , Ross himself declares, "Sport is a common denominator in the world," and is followed by famous athletes reciting pieces of a pledge: "I pledge to treat everyone with respect and dignity. I will not tolerate discrimination or harassment of any kind. I will speak up whenever I know discrimination is happening and I will stand up, get up, rise up for victims."
The first PSAs to be beamed to large public audiences will be:
"Michigan PSA," to be shown on the giant screen at the Big House during Saturday's UM-MSU football game, will feature Tom Brady, former Heisman Trophy winner Desmond Howard, Fab Five basketball payer Jalen Rose and U-M football coach Jim Harbaugh. And "NFL PSA," to be aired on TV during the Miami Dolphins game Sunday, also features New England Patriots and former U-M quarterback Brady, along with other pro football players -- Antonio Brown of Pittsburgh, Ryan Tannehill of Miami, DeMarcus Ware of Denver, Justin Tuck of Oakland and Broncos and Larry Fitzgerald of Arizona. An abbreviated clip of the NFL PSA was to air today on "CBC This Morning." Ross, 75, the New York real estate magnate and philanthropist who has donated more then $300 million to U-M, decided to create the nonprofit RISE last year after one of his Miami Dolphins players, Richie Incognito, had ignited a scandal in 2013 by sending racist and abusive messages to a teammate.

Golden State Warriors forward Draymond Green. (Photo: David J. Phillip, Associated Press)
Jocelyn Benson, dean of the WSU law school, who developed a class on race and sports at WSU back in 2007, was interviewing Ross late last year in New York, when he mentioned the RISE idea.
"I was immediately struck by how extraordinary it was for someone of his stature and caliber to to not just talk about, or speak out against injustice, but actually do something meaningful about it and put his money behind it," Benson said.
Ross, who was born in Detroit and mentored by his late uncle, Detroit business leader and philanthropist Max Fisher, is expected to join other WSU law school alumni tonight for a reception and dinner in Detroit, and to attend the UM-MSU game in Ann Arbor Saturday.

"Athletes, certainly in a high school or college setting, are looked up to as role models, for better or for worse," Benson said. "One of the missions of RISE is to actually train and empower these athletes to be outspoken advocates for racial equality and standing up against harassment and bullying."
At the RISEtoWIN.org site, visitors can pledge to stand up against racism and speak out against discrimination. The “It Takes All Colors” photo app also allows visitors to upload a picture, apply their team colors and share it across social channels.
Tim Richey, CEO of Detroit PAL, said "the fact that we get to be one of the first youth partners to work with RISE is really exciting."

"We have been training our volunteer coaches for a long time in how to use sports to build character," Richey added, but engaging kids to talk about race can be difficult. We know it's important and yet often it’s often the elephant in the room that nobody wants to address head-on."
RISE aims to craft curricula for youth groups like Detroit PAL to use.
